webTitle: Rentokil boss to step down next year

fields.standfirst: Chief executive Alan Brown joined the company in 2008 but failed to turn around its loss-making City Link courier service
fields.body:
Rentokil Initial's chief executive will step down next year, closing a chapter for the company marred by the failed turnaround of a loss-making acquisition.

Alan Brown joined the group, which offers everything from rat-catching products to office plants, in April 2008. He pledged to turn around its struggling courier service, City Link, which the company had bought the previous year.

Five years on, in April this year, City Link was sold for just £1 to Jon Moulton's private equity outfit Better Capital.

When he joined from ICI, Brown brought with him two others in a sweeping revamp of the leadership team. The three – Brown, Andy Ransom and John McAdam, who joined as chairman – were handed a package that could have seen them share more than £90m in bonuses over five years. But all the share targets were missed and the scheme has not paid out.

For the full award of more than £30m each to be triggered, Rentokil's share price would have had to reach 280p this spring. The shares closed at 98p, very close to the price when the three joined.

Ransom, 50, who currently manages the group's operations in the Americas, Europe, Africa and the Middle East, will replace Brown as chief executive in October. Brown will be on hand to support the business until the end of January 2014.

"In 2008 we faced huge challenges. Alan has navigated us through many of them and today we are in a much stronger position to continue our international growth strategy," said McAdam, who remains chairman.

He added that Ransom, who joined the group around the same time as Brown in 2008 and ran its pest control division, was a "natural successor".

webTitle: BAE profits down 8% but firm remains hopeful on £4.5bn Saudi Typhoon order

fields.standfirst: First-half profits stand at £529m as shrinking defence budgets and continued challenging conditions
fields.body:
US state spending cuts contributed to an 8% decline in first-half profits at BAE Systems but the British defence group is hopeful of finally reaching an agreement with Saudi Arabia over the renegotiation of a £4.5bn Typhoon fighter contract.

BAE has been repeatedly weighed down by its failure to settle a price for 72 Eurofighter Typhoon jets, despite securing the order from Saudi Arabia six years ago.

Chief executive Ian King said the company was operating in a "challenging environment" amid shrinking defence budgets but expressed optimism over the chance of signing an agreement before 2014, with analysts estimating that a renegotiation will be worth around £600m to the company.

Saudi Arabia has stopped asking for information from BAE on the order, which suggested a deal was close, according to King. Discussions about expanding the order to up to 72 more aircraft is another sign of progress over the talks, he said.

The FTSE 100 company described the outlook for its UK defence business as "stable", despite the government's austerity drive and pressure on spending.

King said that discussions were continuing with the UK Ministry of Defence over the future of British shipbuilding.

BAE has warned that it might have to stop shipbuilding at least one of its sites, with the spotlight on Portsmouth and its two yards in Glasgow, at Govan and Scotstoun.

"We need to make the right decision for the industrial sector in the UK. It's complex," King said.

Demand in the company's international markets was "strong", with £4.8bn of non-UK and non-US orders received in the first half. It is pursuing potential Typhoon sales in markets including the United Arab Emirates and Malaysia.

BAE was last year forced to abandon plans to merge with European aerospace group and Airbus owner EADS after the German chancellor Angela Merkel personally blocked a deal.

King said on Thursday there were no plans to revive talks with EADS, which is changing its name to Airbus Group.

"We have a very good relationship with them but both companies have moved on."

BAE's order backlog rose 8% to £43.1bn in the first half, the highest since 2009, while sales rose to £8.4bn from £8.3bn a year earlier. Shares in the company rose about 2%.

Centrica chairman Sir Roger Carr will take over as BAE's chairman in the first quarter of 2014, replacing Sir Richard Olver, who came under pressure to step down following the failed merger with EADS.

The board recommended an interim dividend of 8p a share, up from 7.8p a year earlier.

webTitle: Mobile operator 3 triples profits adding 697,000 customers in a year

fields.standfirst: Subscribers signing contracts for top-of-the-range smartphones boost company revenues
fields.body:
3 UK, the mobile network, has more than tripled its profits after adding 697,000 customers in a year.

Operating profits at 3, which is owned by Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa, rose to £86m in the first six months of 2013, up from £26m in the same period last year.

New subscribers willing to sign contracts for top-of-the-range smartphones helped boost the company's revenues 9% year on year, reaching a first half total of £1bn for the first time since the network's launch in 2003.

3's service revenue, from bills for calls, text and internet use, has remained flat at £667m for the first half of the year, but its handset revenues grew 30% to £321m.

The company added a net 168,000 new subscribers in the three months to 30 June, and now has 7.5 million active customers. Active accounts are those that have seen a chargeable activity or incoming calls in the last 90 days.

In common with EE and Vodafone, 3 pays minimal corporation tax in the UK. In 2012 and 2010 it received tax credits from HM Revenue and Customs, and paid just £1.2m in corporation tax in 2011.

The last network to set up shop in Britain, it has fought hard to build a profitable business against its longer established rivals. But after years of losses, 3 reported its first profit in the second half of 2010.

"In building and growing 3 since 2000 we have incurred substantial losses, this is in the nature of massive infrastructure investments," said finance director, Richard Woodward.

"We have thankfully become profitable, but there are obviously still losses to account for. We are committed to growing a profitable business and that will lead to us paying corporation tax, in addition to the taxes we currently pay."

He said 3 was "on track" to launch its answer to EE's superfast mobile internet service before Christmas, with the new 4G network scheduled to go live in the fourth quarter of the year. Three has 900,000 customers who already own a smartphone that will be compatible with its 4G network, and 60% of devices it sells each week are able to run at the faster speeds. All of its customers will receive 4G without having to pay a premium or change their contract.

O2 said Wednesday it would launch its own flavour of 4G on 29 August, with the first masts going live in London, Leeds and Bradford, with plans for an additional 10 cities before the end of the year.

Vodafone is expected to announce its 4G plans next week.

webTitle: Bank of England and ECB leave interest rates unchanged

fields.standfirst: UK interest rates left at their current record low of 0.5%, as are borrowing costs in the eurozone area
fields.body:
The Bank of England has voted to leave UK interest rates at their current record low of 0.5% and decided against a further round of government bond-buying, amid signs of recovery in the UK economy.

The European Central Bank also voted to leave borrowing costs in the euro area unchanged on Thursday, following upbeat data suggesting the eurozone recession is ending.

Both decisions were widely anticipated in the financial markets.

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee decided against making any changes to borrowing costs in Britain at the second MPC meeting to be chaired by new governor Mark Carney. There was no statement, unlike a month ago when the MPC surprised the City and sent shares rallying by saying rates would stay low for longer than investors had predicted.

Analysts believe Carney will announce new "forward guidance" for UK monetary policy at next Wednesday's quarterly inflation report. That guidance is likely to pin future rate rises to specific targets for unemployment, predicted Robert Wood, chief UK economist at Berenberg.

"In our view, the most likely result is that the BoE ties interest rates to a relatively cautious unemployment threshold of 7%. The aim will be to try and keep market interest rate expectations low to allow the nascent recovery to blossom into something stronger and more sustainable," Wood said.

Vicky Redwood of Capital Economics agreed, saying: "Our best guess is that the MPC will commit to keep official interest rates low until an unemployment threshold is breached."

The Bank's decision came after data showed that UK manufacturing confidence had hit the highest level in 28 months, with exports rising and firms hiring more workers. The eurozone's manufacturing sector also saw a rise in activity, according to data firm Markit.

webTitle: Lloyds' share price will delight Osborne. But before he sells it, we need promises

fields.standfirst: The Help to Buy scheme has boosted Lloyds' share price – but the chancellor must ensure it boosts lending before cashing in
fields.body:
Your banking dreams have come true, chancellor. Or, rather, one of them has. While George Osborne thrashes around at Royal Bank of Scotland, changing the chief executive and indulging in a mid-stream strategic rethink, Lloyds Banking Group has today delivered a hallelujah moment. Its share price has finally reached 73p, the price at which the state injected £20bn as part of the grand banking bailout of 2008-09.

What's more, it's a clean break-even number. It doesn't require the inclusion of the insurance fees Lloyds paid under the old asset protection scheme; nor is there a need to reference the lower price of 61p at which the Lloyds shares are booked in the national accounts.

Of course, merely breaking even after five years would count as a miserable return by normal investment yardsticks. But a year ago Lloyds shares were trading at 30p and recovery looked a distant prospect. The bank was swallowing a compensation bill for mis-selling payment protection insurance (and the pain there is not yet over: another £500m charge today takes the tally to £7.28bn) and the economy was still flat.

What's changed? The case for Lloyds was always very simple: as the biggest member of the oligopolistic UK banking industry, it couldn't fail to make a shed-load of money once it had cleansed its stables and the first whiff of economic growth returned. That moment is now in sight.

On the self-help front, chief executive António Horta-Osório has delivered what Osborne wanted – a more UK-focused bank. He has cut the number of Lloyds' overseas operations from 30 to 10. By contrast, Stephen Hester's apparent eagerness to cling to RBS's American unit, Citizens, seems to have been one reason why he got the chop.

Horta-Osório has attacked costs – by £1bn, he says, over the past two years – and Lloyds has benefited from gentler funding conditions for all banks. Meanwhile, charges for bad loans have plunged as the rotten assets have washed through the system.

But the big surprise in today's half-year profit figures was a widening in Lloyds' net interest margin – the difference between the rate at which it lends and the rate it pays depositors. The bank now expects to achieve 2.1% for 2013, well ahead of targets. In part, that's the effect of the chancellor's Help to Buy housing scheme.

Lloyds writes about one-in-four mortgages in the UK – it is a big beneficiary when the housing market becomes more lively. So what's Osborne waiting for? Why doesn't he press the button now and get the state out of Lloyds at the earliest opportunity to record a break-even number? He probably won't wait long. August, in the middle of the holiday season, tends to be regarded as a bad month for selling shares in bulk to City institutions. Meanwhile, Barclays' £5.8bn rights issue approaches – a double helping of bank shares might hit demand.

But those are technical points. In reality, Osborne is probably weighing only two options – selling a portion of the state's shares within days; or waiting until September or October to sell a larger slice. The latter seems more likely.

A moment of national triumph? Up to a point, yes: the government could use the money that will come from turning Lloyds shares into cash. But also consider that the shape of the UK banking industry has hardly been transformed since 2008.

Lloyds will demerge 630 branches under the TSB banner next year and RBS will dispatch 316. But that's about it. UK banking still looks like an oligopoly in which Lloyds is free to maintain the pretence that Halifax is somehow a "challenger" brand even though it sits within a group with an overall market share of about 25%.

Osborne, before he waves a cheery goodbye to Horta-Osório, should insist Lloyds writes in blood a commitment to sustain lending to UK business. It's much easier to do when you still own 39% of the shares.

webTitle: Royal Mail staff to hold strike ballot over privatisation plans

fields.bodyText: More than 100,000 postal workers are to vote on holding a 24-hour nationwide strike in the latest escalation of their battle against the government's plan to privatise the Royal Mail. Communication Workers Union (CWU) representatives voted unanimously on Thursday to ballot 115,000 members on strike action – the first nationwide action since 2009. Dave Ward, deputy general secretary of the CWU, said the ballot would almost certainly lead to strike action, which he believes could scupper the government's plan to sell the 497-year-old postal service. He said the union would "stop at nothing to ensure the future of our members' jobs – and the services they deliver – are protected". Ward accused the government of "completely misleading" the public over the privatisation, which the Treasury hopes will gain the government £3bn. "We have a duty to defend the postal service – and we will," he said. "We are looking for a serious agreement [that] goes to the core of fears about privatisation." Some City institutions, which the government is trying to convince to buy Royal Mail shares in its flotation this autumn, have declined the chance to invest, citing fears of years of industrial unrest. Billy Hayes, general secretary of the CWU, has warned bankers in the City that if they invest in the flotation: "Your shares are not going to be very safe. This is going to be a privatisation against a background of industrial unrest." The union said it did not take the decision to strike lightly and committed itself to continued negotiations with Royal Mail bosses, but also warned that efforts to date "did not bode well". The nationwide strike ballot will be held before the end of September – which will more than likely be before the privatisation. The government has tried to win over workers by offering them an 8.6% pay rise and £2,000 worth of free shares as part of the flotation. But the union rejected the offers as only a "sweetener to swallow some very bitter pills" including privatisation and damaging changes to pensions and working conditions. "There hasn't yet been a pay rise for staff this year despite healthy company profits of £403m million. But most importantly, we want protections for job security and terms and conditions and these are sadly lacking," Ward added. CWU members have voted 96% against privatisation, and 99% back the union's position on pay. Royal Mail said it was disappointed that the CWU was calling for a national strike ballot and warned that disrupting customers' deliveries would not help the union's campaign against privatisation."A highly competitive pay offer and agreement has been proposed to the CWU and has been rejected. Talks are on-going and we are committed to seeking an agreement. We believe that a ballot on strike action is inappropriate." A spokesman for the department for business, which is selling Royal Mail on behalf of the government, said it was "very disappointing" that the ballot will go ahead and repeated its commitment to the sell off.

webTitle: Letter from Lloyds Banking Group chief executive to shareholders

fields.standfirst: 'Following the recent announcement of our 2013 half year results, I am writing to update you, as a shareholder in Lloyds Banking Group, on the progress we are making ... '
fields.body:
Dear Shareholder,

Following the recent announcement of our 2013 half year results, I am writing to update you, as a shareholder in Lloyds Banking Group, on the progress we are making on our strategy to make your bank into the best bank for customers.

SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS IN DELIVERING OUR STRATEGIC PLAN

I am pleased to report that we have made substantial progress in the two years since we set out our strategy to transform the Group by strengthening it, reshaping it to focus on our core UK business, reducing costs and risk significantly, and simplifying and improving our service, products and processes. As a result we are now well on track to create a bank we can all be proud of, and which I expect to deliver strong, stable and sustainable returns to you.

STRENGTHENING THE GROUP

Strengthening and stabilising the Group has been a priority over the past two years. We have successfully reshaped the Group's balance sheet, and substantially reduced those assets and businesses that we do not believe are core to our future plan. We have also significantly reduced our dependence on wholesale funding, whilst strengthening our capital and liquidity positions. We have continued to address legacy issues, such as PPI, and we have sought to do this in the best interests of both our customers and our shareholders.

SIMPLIFYING THE GROUP AND SUPPORTING OUR CUSTOMERS

We are now far more efficient, having simplified the bank from our customers' point of view, whilst simultaneously reducing costs by over £1 billion. We have reduced our global footprint, so that we can focus on our core UK business, such that by the end of this year we will be operating in around 10 countries, down from 30 countries two years ago.

The Group's transformation allows us to better support our business and personal customers, by offering better value products and enhanced services.

This is having a significant impact. Our net lending to small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs), which are a key driver of growth and employment, has grown by around 4% per annum over the past two years. This is in marked contrast to the market overall, which fell by around 4% per annum over the same period. We have also continued to support our personal customers through improving service, and in targeting specific areas, including first time buyers in the UK where we will help more than 60,000 people buy their first home in 2013.

As importantly, we have reduced costs while improving our quality of service, with customer satisfaction increasing and customer complaints now substantially lower than for all of our main competitors. In addition, we are the only major bank that has not reduced its branch network and we have committed to keep our branches open when we are the last bank in town.

A SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN PROFIT

In terms of our financial performance, the actions we are taking have put us ahead of plan and resulted in a significant increase in profit in the first half of 2013. You will be able to find further detail on our 2013 Half-Year Results on our website. We expect further positive progress on our strategy in the rest of this year. We have a strongly capital generative business, we expect to reduce costs further and to grow our core loan book.

LAUNCHING TSB AND LLOYDS BANK ON TO THE UK HIGH STREET

I want also to update you briefly on progress on the business divestment that the European Commission has required the Group to make. We are creating two separate banks from Lloyds TSB: Lloyds Bank and TSB. You will see the new TSB branches on our high streets in the autumn. It is expected to have nationwide branch coverage with around 630 branches, and approximately five million customers. At the same time we will use the opportunity to rebrand our Lloyds branches as Lloyds Bank. We now intend to sell the new TSB through an Initial Public Offering, with our aim remaining to obtain best value for shareholders, as well as certainty for our customers and colleagues.

DELIVERING SUSTAINABLE BENEFITS FOR CUSTOMERS, COLLEAGUES AND SHAREHOLDERS

The strategy we set out in June 2011, to simplify the organisation and focus on UK retail and commercial banking, is the right strategy for Lloyds Banking Group. The rise in our share price confirms that the market supports this view. The Group's share price has increased by 41% in the two years following the announcement of the Strategic Review, the largest increase of any UK bank over that period and since January 2012 by 144%, the largest increase among the top 20 banks in the world.

Over time, I believe our plan to transform the Group will make us the best bank for customers and ensure we help Britain prosper. It will also enable us to realise our full potential to deliver strong, stable and sustainable returns for you our shareholders and ultimately to allow the UK taxpayers' investment in the Group to be repaid.

Finally, I would like to thank you for your loyalty and commitment as a shareholder. I intend to send you an update on our progress twice a year and will write to you again following the release of our Full Year Results in the first quarter of next year.

Yours faithfully

António Horta-Osório

Group Chief Executive

webTitle: UK manufacturing confidence highest since 2011

fields.standfirst: Survey for June found a sharp increase in both orders and production, providing fresh evidence of a pick-up in the economy
fields.body:
Business conditions in Britain's manufacturing sector rose to their highest level in almost two-and-a-half years last month, providing fresh evidence of a pick-up in the economy.

The monthly survey of industry from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply and Markit found a sharp increase in both orders and production.

After suffering badly during the recession and the UK's sluggish recovery, Thursday's survey showed that the Purchasing Managers' Index – a barometer of manufacturing's strength – rose from 52.9 in June to 54.6 in July. Any reading above 50 indicates an expanding sector.

The CIPS/Markit report continued the improvement in the outlook for manufacturing seen over the past five months, with companies reporting stronger demand both at home and abroad.

Companies selling consumer goods reported the strongest trading conditions in July, but there was also increased activity for firms specialising in investment and intermediate goods.

UK manufacturers ran down their stocks to meet demand and expanded their workforces for the third month. Industry reported that inflationary pressure remained weak.

New export orders increased at their fastest pace in two years, reflecting higher sales to China, Australia, Kenya, Nigeria, Mexico, Russia and the United States.

There was also an improvement in exports to the eurozone, where the manufacturing PMI moved above 50 for the first time in two years last month.

Boosting hopes that the single currency area will finally emerge from an 18-month double dip recession in the second half of 2013, the PMI moved up from 48.8 in June to 50.3 in July.

David Noble, chief executive officer at the Chartered Institute of Purchasing & Supply said: "The much-vaunted march of the makers has finally materialised with the UK manufacturing sector's output growth hitting a 29-month high in July. Exports have been critical to this success, but it is the broad based nature of the sector's performance which endorses the view we are on track for solid and accelerated growth in the coming months."

James Knightley, economist at ING, said: "This (report) suggests that the third quarter started on a strong footing and with other business surveys also suggesting that the UK economy is gaining momentum it indicates little need for further Bank of England policy stimulus. Today's Monetary Policy Committee meeting should be a non-event as we await for the BoE's assessment on forward guidance next week. This is clearly going to be the policy option of choice from here on as the Bank seeks to keep accommodative monetary conditions in place to ensure the recovery continues."

webTitle: Bank levy to raise $733m as Rudd government strives for surplus

fields.standfirst: Customers expected to bear cost of levy, which will create bailout fund but also go to government's bottom line
fields.body:
A new levy on Australia's banks will raise $733m, adding to a tobacco tax rise worth $5.3bn to be unveiled in the Rudd government's looming economic statement.

The government will create a financial stability fund recommended by the International Monetary Fund, the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Council of Financial Regulators, paid for by the levy on the banks.

The fund is designed as insurance in the event that a big Australian bank requires a bailout owing to global instability.

The levy will be collected by the banking regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, and deposited into a fund administered by a government agency. The money will be quarantined but, for accounting purposes, will go to the bottom line. The measure will help the government meet its surplus target for 2016-17.

The levy is not expected to take effect until January 2016. The government envisages imposing a notional 5 basis points levy on deposits of up to $250,000 for each account holder at every bank, mutual bank or credit union.

Banks are expected to pass the cost of the levy to their customers. Speculation about an imminent levy hit bank stocks heavily on Thursday, with some down 2% before recovering later in the afternoon.

The proposed bank levy adds to a substantial jump in tobacco tax that will deliver more than $5bn to the federal budget between now and 2016.

The treasurer, Chris Bowen, confirmed on Thursday that tax on tobacco would rise 12.5% over the next four years. The government has been attempting to frame the revenue grab as a health measure, pointing to the preventive health issues it is also undertaking.

The increases will begin on 1 December. Further rises will follow on 1 September 2014, 1 September 2015 and 1 September 2016. The tax rise is in addition to increases that would have occurred through indexation.

Bowen said the move would bring Australia closer to the taxation standard recommended by the World Health Organisation. "This I know won't be universally popular at all," he said. "It's a difficult decision. But it's a decision which is taken in the best interests of the nation taking account all the impacts it has, both on the government's budget and also on the health outcomes for Australia."

Bowen told reporters in Sydney on Thursday morning the $5.3bn tobacco tax rise was a "substantial" measure; one of the biggest revenue measures in the government's economic statement expected on Friday.

He also confirmed that the statement would outline the full costs of the regional resettlement agreement with Papua New Guinea. The government has thus far declined to quantify the costs of that deal.

The government faces a difficult task to meet its commitment to return the budget to surplus in 2016-17. Tax revenues have been weak and the government must offset spending associated with policy changes made by Kevin Rudd since he returned to the Labor leadership.

Bowen and the prime minister began to soften the ground for the tobacco tax increase on Wednesday at separate events in Sydney and Brisbane. "As the prime minister said today, we need to be continually looking at what we can do to reduce smoking," Bowen said on Wednesday afternoon.

"There is not a family in Australia that hasn't been touched by cancer caused by smoking. I think the Australian people would agree with us, that we need to consider all sorts of measures to reduce smoking."

Labor has been active throughout its two terms in government to reduce smoking, winning a landmark high court case that imposed plain packaging on the tobacco industry.

The Cancer Council has endorsed the tax rise. Its chief executive, Professor Ian Olver, said price control through tax was by far the most effective public health measure to bring down smoking rates, particularly among young people and people on lower incomes.

"Evidence shows that the increase in excise in 2010 has driven down tobacco consumption by around 11 per cent," Olver said.

There is speculation the government will use the release of the economic statement as a springboard for calling the federal election for 7 September.

The Coalition has been critical of the tobacco measure. It says the government should seek to control spending rather than raise taxes, particularly those impacting disproportionately on low income earners. "This is just another tax. Let's not listen to this palaver about health, it's all about revenue," the opposition leader, Tony Abbott, told reporters in Melbourne on Thursday morning.

Abbott said the opposition would respond to the statement once it was in the public domain. He would not be drawn on specific measures until then.

"This is a government that can't control its spending," he said. "Whenever it gets into trouble, it hits you, the Australian people, with new taxes. If they do this to you before the election, think how much worse it will be after the election."

webTitle: Shell profits hit by Nigeria disruption

fields.standfirst: Europe's biggest oil company says oil thefts and gas supply problems in Nigeria helped knock profits down to $4.6bn
fields.body:
Oil thefts and gas supply disruptions in Nigeria contributed to a large fall in profits at Royal Dutch Shell in the second quarter.

Europe's biggest oil company was also hit by the tax impact of a weaker Australian dollar, with profits falling to $4.6bn (£3bn) from $6bn in the same period last year.

The results were worse than analysts expected, and were described by Shell's outgoing chief executive, Peter Voser, as "disappointing". Shell was among the biggest fallers in the FTSE 100 in early trading, down around 4%.

The company took a one-off hit of $2.2bn in the period, mainly related to the exploration and drilling of liquids-rich shale sites in North America. Profits were down 60% when the charge was included. "Higher costs, exploration charges, adverse currency exchange rate effects and challenges in Nigeria have hit our bottom line. These results were undermined by a number of factors – but they were clearly disappointing for Shell," said Voser.

He said Shell would "play our part" in Nigeria but added the company could not solve the problems alone.

Shell said it would accelerate the rate of disposals from the $21bn of assets it has sold over the past three years. It has launched a strategic review in North America and Nigeria, which will lead to further disposals.

The company said dividends paid out in the quarter totalled $2.8bn.

webTitle: What cost of living pressure?

fields.standfirst: Cost of living increases are at a historic low, but you're highly unlikely to hear a politician say so
fields.body:
The one issue all political parties always agree on is that cost of living is something we need to be concerned about.

When Kevin Rudd announced that he was scrapping the fixed price for carbon and moving to a floating rate, rather than talk of it as an environment policy, he defined it in terms of “cost of living”. He said: “The government has decided to terminate the carbon tax to help cost of living pressures for families and to reduce costs for small business.”

The Liberal party’s policy pamphlet Real Solutions does much the same thing, referring throughout to “cost of living pressures” – especially with regards to electricity and gas prices as a result of the carbon tax.

No politician is ever able to suggest that these pressures are not real, nor that they are even getting better, for fear of being labelled as “out of touch”. The problem, however, is that the latest data from the ABS shows that increases in cost of living for most households are as low as they have been in the past 20 years (outside of the GFC).

While the usual CPI inflation figures treat everyone as part of the same average type of household, the ABS’s Cost of Living Indices measure inflation according to how it is felt by four household types: employee households, age pensioner households, other government transfer recipient households and self-funded retiree households. The cost of living index also counts things not included in the CPI figure – most importantly the interest rate paid on mortgages.

Quite often you hear people say that the CPI is not reflective of the real-world impact of price rises. The cost of living index tries to overcome these concerns. But what it often highlights is that the CPI is actually a pretty good overall measure,

For households with employees (around 70% of all households), the current annual rise in cost of living is actually lower than CPI. Moreover, at 1.4% it’s well below anything seen in the past decade other than during the GFC:

For aged-pensioner households, the increase in cost of living is slightly higher than CPI:

This is not surprising. Employee households are more likely to have a mortgage and thus they benefit more from falling interest rates than do pensioners who have paid off their home loan.

But for all household groups the increase in cost of living is currently lower than it was at the last election.

So if cost of living is actually rising slower than in the past, why does it remain such a hot-button issue?

Part of the reason is that while overall inflation is low, electricity prices increased markedly in the past 12 months due to the carbon price and network costs (both were roughly responsible for half of the average 17% increase). Electricity and other utilities now only account for around 3.6% of households’ total expenditure each year, but unlike the amount spent on alcohol for example (on average 4.75% of households’ annual expenditure), electricity prices come in a big bill and are also not a luxury item.

So to an extent it is understandable why people feel that cost of living is growing faster than ever because the big bills you notice are going up faster than the small bills which you don’t notice so much.

But cost of living isn’t just about prices. When times are good you worry about keeping up with inflation, when times are poor the reason you worry about being able to pay for things is due to declining income – whether due to loss of a job or a cut in hours of work.

The current cost of living concern is also abetted by the changes in the economy since the GFC. This was mentioned again in a speech by the Reserve Bank governor, Glenn Stevens, on Tuesday when he noted that “the value of non-financial assets in particular – mainly dwellings – is lower today in real per person terms than it was five years ago”.

Although increasing housing prices actually raise the cost of living they also increase household wealth. Thus conversely a slow growth in housing prices reduces the actual cost of living, and also serves to make people feel like their wealth is not growing as fast it was – and thus the sense that prices are increasing faster than is their wealth.

So “cost of living pressure” morphs into whatever context is appropriate for the time – inflation, job security, reduced assets prices, declining wealth.

It’s why those waiting for politicians to stop wheeling out the phrase will wait in vain. But given the latest data shows that the actual increase in cost of living is historically low, the debate might benefit from calling things for what they are. It would also be good if politicians could state facts without being branded as out of touch.

Moreover, at 1.4% it’s well below anything seen in the past decade other than during the GFC: For aged-pensioner households, the increase in cost of living is slightly higher than CPI: This is not surprising. Employee households are more likely to have a mortgage and thus they benefit more from falling interest rates than do pensioners who have paid off their home loan. But for all household groups the increase in cost of living is currently lower than it was at the last election. So if cost of living is actually rising slower than in the past, why does it remain such a hot-button issue? Part of the reason is that while overall inflation is low, electricity prices increased markedly in the past 12 months due to the carbon price and network costs (both were roughly responsible for half of the average 17% increase). Electricity and other utilities now only account for around 3.6% of households’ total expenditure each year, but unlike the amount spent on alcohol for example (on average 4.75% of households’ annual expenditure), electricity prices come in a big bill and are also not a luxury item. So to an extent it is understandable why people feel that cost of living is growing faster than ever because the big bills you notice are going up faster than the small bills which you don’t notice so much. But cost of living isn’t just about prices. When times are good you worry about keeping up with inflation, when times are poor the reason you worry about being able to pay for things is due to declining income – whether due to loss of a job or a cut in hours of work. The current cost of living concern is also abetted by the changes in the economy since the GFC. This was mentioned again in a speech by the Reserve Bank governor, Glenn Stevens, on Tuesday when he noted that “the value of non-financial assets in particular – mainly dwellings – is lower today in real per person terms than it was five years ago”. Although increasing housing prices actually raise the cost of living they also increase household wealth. Thus conversely a slow growth in housing prices reduces the actual cost of living, and also serves to make people feel like their wealth is not growing as fast it was – and thus the sense that prices are increasing faster than is their wealth. So “cost of living pressure” morphs into whatever context is appropriate for the time – inflation, job security, reduced assets prices, declining wealth. It’s why those waiting for politicians to stop wheeling out the phrase will wait in vain. But given the latest data shows that the actual increase in cost of living is historically low, the debate might benefit from calling things for what they are. It would also be good if politicians could state facts without being branded as out of touch.
fields.headline: What cost of living pressure?
fields.trailText: Cost of living increases are at a historic low, but you're highly unlikely to hear a politician say so
